casualties.incident_precis: A crane sling broke, dropping a 25-ton tank of hazardous chlorine gas on deck during loading. Jordanian media reported the tank exploded, resulting in a “massive release of poisonous gas.” Aqaba beaches were evacuated, and shipping was halted.   Over 120 of those injured were hospitalized.

The ship ran into gale-force winds and 9-meter waves while returning to the U.K. from a two-week cruise in the Canary Islands. Reportedly, most of the injuries were minor but there were reports of lacerations with some people requiring stitches and broken bones. Five people were hospitalized “as a precaution” upon arrival in England.

Norwegian authorities said the vessel was “a ship’s length from running aground” after “insufficient lubricating oil in all of the operating diesel generators” caused a blackout during a storm. Large waves crashed through glass doors, injuring dozens of people. Helicopters carried nearly 500 passengers to safety before the captain stopped the evacuation due to the weather. At least 36 were hospitalized.
The ship was ordered back to port in Malaysia after smoke was detected coming from several containers stacked onboard. Dozens of firefighters eventually extinguished flames in 13 containers.

Nineteen dock workers and two emergency services personnel were treated after corrosive valeric acid leaked onboard. They complained of respiratory irritation, nausea, and vomiting. Some patients were hospitalized, while the majority sustained slight injuries.

A devastating fire destroyed over 2,700 cars on board and collapsed the upper decks of the ship. Rescue helicopters evacuated 23 crew members. The injured were treated for breathing problems, burns, and broken bones, local Dutch authorities said.

Large waves broke several windows of the passenger cabins, killing a 62-year-old American woman and injuring four others during an Antarctic cruise. The vessel sustained some damage and arrived in Ushuaia, Argentina, the next day. Viking called it a “rogue wave incident” and said the four other passengers’ injuries were not life-threatening.

The Indian navy rescued 21 crew members after Houthi forces fired a missile, lighting the ship on fire and killing three. A French war vessel later shot down four Houthi drones to protect the ongoing salvage of the abandoned ship. One of the seafarers had a serious leg injury requiring amputating, while another suffered major burns.
The Francis Scott Key bridge collapsed atop the ship after it lost power and struck a support pillar. The incident killed several construction workers who fell into the Patapsco River below.

While shifting between berths at the Port of Bataan, Philippines, the ship collided with the 140-metre dredger Hong Hai 189, which eventually sank. One man drowned, while the ship’s safety officer died from head injuries.
Two seafarers suffered minor burns to the face and hands while three others sustained superficial injuries when methane ignited in a carpenter’s workshop. The vessel was undamaged.

The Philippine fishing vessel Dearyn was moored over a human-made structure anchored offshore to attract fish, when the Pacific Anna collided with it. Reports state the fishermen didn’t spot the approaching tanker due to the dark evening and poor weather. Eight fishermen survived, using smaller boats to carry their dead captain and two other victims to a nearby port.
Two workers were taken to a local hospital when an unloader funnel fell on a road truck during the discharge of sodium sulfate from the ship.
The third engineer and a mechanic were severely burned in a “work incident” while en route from Singapore to China. A rescue vessel evacuated the inured.
casualties.location: 175 nautical miles southeast of Vung Tau, Vietnam

casualties.incident_precis: The vessel’s master reported sighting six intruders armed with knives near the engine room. The intruders threw spanners at the crew during a standoff, injuring a motorman’s hand and a third engineer’s head. They escaped in a small boat after the ship’s alarm was raised.
Two seafarers died when the engine room caught fire. Crew brought the fire under control, and the ship was later towed to Lisbon, Portugal.
A reported accident aboard the chemical tanker killed one crew member and seriously injured another while en route to Naples. The injured seafarer was flown by helicopter to a hospital in Naples.

Two external technicians performing a routine inspection of the ship’s cargo tanks were found unconscious in one of the tanks. One died on the way to the hospital, while the other died at the hospital. Cause of death was reported as asphyxiation.

casualties.subsidiary_list: Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement (Hong Kong) Limited Partnership
casualties.incident_precis: The container ship ran aground and came to rest across the Suez Canal, blocking the route for nearly a week. One person died during efforts to salvage the ship, according to Suez Canal Authority Chair Osama Rabie.

casualties.summary: Beneficial owner, ISM manager, Commerical operator, Registered owner, Technical manager
casualties.subsidiary_list: Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement (UK) Limited; Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement (Isle of Man) Limited; The Schulte Group; Baldwin Shipping Limited
casualties.incident_precis: While working on a fuel filter, a newly promoted engineer had not effectively isolated the fuel system, leading to a fire in the engine room. The sailor died nine days later of effects of smoke inhalation. An investigation found the third engineer died while attempting an "unnecessary job conducted in an unsafe way at an inappropriate time.”
A suspected attack while about 14 miles off Iran’s coast damaged the tanker’s hull. Its 21 crew members abandoned the vessel, which was later towed to port.

Ten armed, hooded men boarded the ship in an apparent attempt to recover 529 kilos of cocaine that had been hidden in the ship’s hull. “What they obviously did not know was that the drugs were seized by customs officials on Oct 2,” reports stated. The crew was tied up and several injured during the hijack.

Smoke rising from a fire in the ship’s engine room was spotted from many parts of Mersin, Turkey. The fire was quickly extinguished, but one crew member was taken to the hospital with burns on the face and arms.
While coming into its berth, the ship struck another ship and three cranes at the port. The crane operator leapt from a height of five meters in an attempt to escape, injuring an ankle.

Bad weather caused a collision after the mooring boat PMB VI finished unloading the Enduro’s cargo. Three crew members jumped into the water as the mooring boat sank, but the captain was trapped inside and died.
While en route to West Thurrock, the 54-year-old, Ukrainian master of the ship had a medical emergency. He was reported unconscious, but breathing and “changing color.” He was later pronounced dead.
Several steel plates, weighing between 300 and 500 kilograms, fell on a man in a storage room while at the Mukran ferry port in Germany. He died at the scene.
Winds from Storm Eunice broke loose a mooring rope, whipping them into a crew member’s head. He was taken to Royal London Hospital and later died.

The ship struck two cranes while coming into port. Both cranes collapsed, “wreaking havoc on the quayside,” according to reports. Several stacked containers were damaged or destroyed, getting caught under the crane wreckage. One worker was slightly injured and had to be hospitalized. The two crane operators got trapped in their cabins, but later rescued.

A crewman working in a hold containing palm kernel, which is known to deplete oxygen in the air, was found unconscious and taken to the hospital. The captain and chief officer pleaded guilty to providing false information to New Zealand authorities, while the captain also pleaded guilty to permitting dangerous activity. They were fined thousands of dollars.

As the Bow Dalian was moored alongside and transferring chemicals with another ship, an explosion caught the other ship on fire. It eventually spread to the Bow Dalian. All 49 crew members on board both vessels were rescued.

The boom of a crane ended up draped over the Prosperity after a pier collapsed and the crane fell into the water. Several workers sustained minor injuries in the collapse, and two fell into the water. One was quickly rescued, but the body of the second, a Bangladeshi man, was recovered after an extended search.
casualties.location: South China, Indo China, Indonesia and Philippines

casualties.incident_precis: A crew member died in his cabin, “probably due to Covid-19” as the ship was en route from Los Angeles to Peru. Five of 18 crew members on board tested positive for the coronavirus as it was quarantined off the coast of Ecuador.

Seven crew members tested positive for Covid-19 after the vessel arrived in Norway. The vessel had requested medical assistance for the crew, but the captain died before help arrived. He tested positive for the coronavirus post-mortem.

casualties.subsidiary_list: V. Ships Ship Management India Private Limited
casualties.incident_precis: When pirates abducted 20 Indian crew members and held them hostage for about a month, one of the crew became “very ill during the attack.” He died despite receiving medical assistance from his captors.
casualties.location: 110 nautical miles off the coast of Benin

casualties.summary: Beneficial owner, ISM manager, Commerical operator, Registered owner, Technical manager
casualties.subsidiary_list: Wilhelmsen Ship Management Korea Limited; EUKOR Car Carriers Incorporated; Wilh. Wilhelmsen Holding ASA (Wilship); Lisa International Maritime SA
casualties.incident_precis: A man died after he was trapped under a forklift that overturned on board the vehicle carrier while at port. The fire department had to free him with hydraulic equipment.
A 40-year-old crew member died after falling from the cruise ship while it was anchored. The man was airlifted to the Aberdeen Royal Infirmary but died from his injuries.

casualties.summary: Beneficial owner, Commerical operator, Registered owner
casualties.subsidiary_list: Wallenius Wilhelmsen Ocean Holding AS; Wilh Wilhelmsen ASA (WILSHIP); WWL Shipowning Singapore Private Limited
casualties.incident_precis: A Filipino crew member died on board with symptoms of Covid-19 as the vehicle carrier traveled from Chile to South Korea. The ship was allowed to dock in Ecuador for “humanitarian reasons” to remove the corpse.

A pilot was injured while climbing on board the vessel. U.S. Coast Guard inspectors noted an improper ladder was being used and there was no checklist for the ladder’s rigging. “The accident provides objective evidence of a need for a procedure to ensure the safety of personnel,” inspectors wrote.
The U.S. Coast Guard incident investigation report has not been released, but records show inspectors in St. Croix reported an unspecified crew member injury.

While the crane operator was lifting 9 to 10 tons of sulphur with a deck crane, the hoisting cable parted and snapped back through the window of the crane. It struck the crane operator on the left hand, leaving a two-inch laceration. The operator was seen at a local hospital as a precautionary measure.

While mooring at Fairport, Ohio, a Filipino ordinary seaman was standing near a steel wire being used as a mooring line. A Bengali third mate operating a winch warned him in English to move, but the wire snapped up abruptly as it tightened. It struck the Filipino man’s shoulder and head, flinging him into the air. He landed on his shoulder and back, dislocating his hip. Coast Guard records blame the third mate’s inexperience and a language barrier.
casualties.location: Grand River, east of Cleveland, Ohio

casualties.incident_precis: While mooring, the line drooped into the water between the vessel and pier. As the crew was using a winch to take slack out of the line, the ship shifted, catching the line between its side and the pier. It snapped loose suddenly, striking the jaw and right arm of a second officer peering over the ship’s side, knocking him to the deck. He received stitches for a chin laceration and was diagnosed with a minor concussion.

During routine maintenance on a cylinder on the main diesel engine, a second engineer missed a chisel rod, striking a third engineer’s right hand with a heavy-duty, 15-inch steel drill hammer. The third engineer was wearing heavy leather gloves, but the blow fractured his little finger and required 12 stitches.

En route from Dutch Harbor, Alaska, to Russia, a passenger using a cane lost his balance and fell as he entered a restaurant for dinner service. The initial report was a broken hip, but a doctor reported no fractures — just bruising to the passenger’s elbow and hip.

casualties.subsidiary_list: Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement (Deutschland) GmbH & Company KG
casualties.incident_precis: A Filipino fitter experiencing severe stomach pain became unresponsive as he was being transferred to another ship for evacuation to Staten Island University Hospital. CPR was started, but the crew member was pronounced dead when the ship arrived at the pier.
casualties.location: South of Long Island, New York

casualties.incident_precis: The chemical tanker was traveling from New York to Port Arthur, Texas, to discharge its cargo. While off the coast of Miami, Florida, crew members discovered the vessel’s relief captain with a towel around his neck and the other end tied to a bathroom handle. His vital signs were weak and CPR was provided. The vessel moored in the Bahamas, but was denied approval to land with the body, so it headed for Mississippi.
casualties.location: Off the coast of Miami, Florida

casualties.incident_precis: A seaman’s right thigh was impaled upon a large bolt attached to a forklift. He was assisting a crane operator with moving the forklift from its cradle on the upper deck to the main deck. He signaled to the crane operator to lift the machine but then “stepped into a dangerous area behind the forklift.” As the machine raised, it swung on the crane’s hook, impaling the bolt into the man’s leg. He was taken to a local hospital for surgery to repair the puncture wound.
A crew member was found unresponsive in their stateroom and was later pronounced dead due to a pre-existing medical condition.
casualties.location: Mississippi River, south of New Orleans

casualties.incident_precis: The bosun slipped on ice and fell onto his back on a ladder connecting the rescue boat deck and the poop deck. He strained his right hand while trying to cling onto the railings. He experienced “excruciating pain in his left shoulder” and was diagnosed with a left-side bone bruise.
